text: Human monocyte binding to <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhances <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced early signaling events .
Leukocyte integrins are fundamentally important in modulating adhesion to extracellular matrix components and to other cells .
This integrin - mediated adhesion controls leukocyte arrest and extravasation during the onset of inflammatory responses .
Moreover , integrin - ligand interactions trigger signaling pathways that may influence leukocyte phenotype and function at sites of inflammation .
In the current studies , we evaluated the combinatorial effects of monocyte adhesion and <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on intracellular signaling pathways .

<extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> triggers a well-defined signal transduction pathway , which although not directly stimulated by monocyte adherence to <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or arginine-glycine-aspartate ( RGD ) - coated substrata , was enhanced significantly in these matrix-adherent cells .

Compared with monocytes in suspension or adherent on plastic surfaces , monocytes adherent to <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or RGD exhibited a greater than threefold increase in steady state levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced mRNA for the <extra_id_0> high affinity Fc gammaRI receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: These results suggest a novel mechanism by which integrin - mediated cell adhesion can modulate the magnitude of cytokine - induced signal transduction pathways , thereby amplifying cellular events leading to monocyte activation and inflammation .
